title: Jonathan Graves
text:
Welcome to my GitHub Homepage!
This is a small repository to allow open access to some of my teaching and data curation resources. I‚Äôm slowly migrating and adding files to this, so keep an eye out.
You can email me at jonathan.graves@ubc.ca






Tip




Looking for the COMET project? Or the repo?
You may also want to check out my online workshops
Or my Quarto extensions!
Or you can check out my faculty web-page

title: Cool Data Resources
text:
Over time, I‚Äôve been slowly collecting interesting datasets and places where datasets are located to help students locate or get inspired about data. Here is my current list - if you have suggestions, email me to add them at jonathan.graves@ubc.ca or submit an issue here!
If you‚Äôre searching for an idea, browse around and see if there‚Äôs a cool dataset you think might be fun to explore.
Other Notes:

title: Cool Data Resources
text:
:x clicky
Just like this!

title: Cool Data Resources
text:
Reference Sites

Pro Football Reference (NFL) - http://www.pro-football-reference.com/
Basketball Reference - NBA/WNBA - NBA/WNBA - http://www.basketball-reference.com/

https://www.pbpstats.com/
https://www.nba.com/stats

Hockey Reference (NHL) - http://www.hockey-reference.com/
Football Reference (Soccer) - http://fbref.com/

title: Cool Data Resources
text:
Baseball

Retrosheet: literally every single baseball play and event since 1915. https://www.retrosheet.org/game.htm

It is painful and ancient, but new generations must suffer!

‚òÜ Fangraphs - Baseball: your single source for all stats baseball. https://www.fangraphs.com/

:Comment from JS

Baseball Savant: very detailed, MLB-sourced data on raw stats. https://baseballsavant.mlb.com/

:Comment from JS

Baseball Reference: a more modern version of Retrosheet, without the suffering. Historical data. https://www.baseball-reference.com/

:Comment from JS

baseballr: you know it exists. A baseball data API, pulling from most of the above. There‚Äôs also a Python version. https://billpetti.github.io/baseballr/

:Comment from JS

title: Cool Data Resources
text:
R-packages for Sports

cfbfastR - College Football - https://github.com/sportsdataverse/cfbfastR
hoopR - NBA - https://github.com/sportsdataverse/hoopR
wehoop - WNBA/NCAA Womens - https://github.com/sportsdataverse/wehoop
sportyR - Visualization Package - https://github.com/sportsdataverse/sportyR
chessR - Chess - https://github.com/jaseziv/chessR/
fastRhockey - NHL/PHF - https://github.com/sportsdataverse/fastRhockey
worldfootballR - International Football (Soccer) - https://github.com/jaseziv/worldfootballR/


Someone who knows about cricket or American football make me some suggestions!

There are many more options out there, so keep your eyes open!

title: Cool Data Resources
text:
:x comment1
I can‚Äôt express how much I love this website. I‚Äôve spent hundreds of hours browsing it, and it‚Äôs perfect in nearly every way. I wouldn‚Äôt be enrolled in this class right now without Fangraphs, and I say that with absolute certainty. In terms of its function, it‚Äôs a one stop shop for all things Sabermetrics - from basic stats like Retrosheet, to hyper advanced ones, to articles, to projection models, to scouting, to community research. This website is the backbone of the analytically inclined baseball community. - JS

title: Cool Data Resources
text:
:x comment2
Baseball Savant is a MLB run site dedicated to Statcast, an initiative introduced in 2015 to collect data from every action that takes place on the field through the lenses of around a dozen high frame rate cameras (75-300fps). Compared to FanGraphs, which is primarily calculated metrics from in-game results, all Statcast metrics have a level of rawness to them. Instead of ERA, you will find average exit velocity and launch angle. - JS

title: Cool Data Resources
text:
:x comment3
Baseball Reference is essentially the 2022 version of Retrosheet. For those who are more interested in historical research, this is the best option available. - JS

title: Cool Data Resources
text:
:x comment4
When it comes to running more intensive data analysis, I prefer to utilize this API package to receive data. It is directly linked to Statcast data, as well as FanGraphs, which makes it super easy. Also, to my understanding this (and a similar package for Python) are the only methods of retrieving raw play-by-play statcast data, which is necessary in creating advanced models - JS

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Replicability in Economics
As Ioannidis (2005) argues, most research findings are false.

Flexibility in research findings leads to numerous false positives.
Publication bias means many papers never see the light of day (Franco, Malhotra, and Simonovits (2014)), overstating and contaminating meta-analyses.

This has led to the replication crisis in many fields (esp.¬†social psychology) in which seemings well-established results just‚Ä¶ aren‚Äôt true.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Economics is not Immune

Figure 1 from Brodeur et al. (2016)

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Reasons for Non-Replication
This is not (usually) malfeasance on the part of a research. It‚Äôs just bad practice, and a lack of transparency.

Not keeping track of code and data sources in sufficient detail
Software versions changing or packages no longer being available
Insufficient detail in code about analyses performed in drawing results
Changes to underlying raw data (e.g., BLS Adjustments)

As Christensen and Miguel (2018) argues, this is a solvable problem with better research practices.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Why Replicable?
One part of the solution is replicable research workflows. The key benefits:

Transparent, reproducible results and research outputs
Easy to detect errors and correct mistakes
Easy to share results with co-authors and colleagues
More likely to get published, even with null results

Key Drawback: more work if not executed properly.

This presentation: tips on how to make this part of your workflow, and eliminate the drawback.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
The Replicable Workflow




 
flowchart LR
    A[(Raw Data)] --> B[Data Clean-up] 
    B --> C{Analysis}
    C --> D(Main Results) --- P>Paper]
    C --> E(Appendix Results)
    E --- Q>Appendices]





Each step here should be documented and replicable.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
What is Environment Management?
One key issue is making sure you can easily re-create all of the tools (software) you need to do an analysis.

This is challenging, since software is constantly changing.
If you just install R or Python on your computer:

Which version? Which packages?


Moreover, you might install something else which breaks something you need (e.g., LaTeX)

A key solution is environment management.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Key Benefits?
A environment is a virtualized computational environment with defined properties which are tracked.

Think of it like a computer-within-a-computer.

The key benefits are that:

You know exactly what is in the environment, and can restore, update, and revert it as needed
Your environment is isolated from the rest of your PC and other environments. Installing a new package will not affect anything outside of the environment.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Options
There are many environment managers out there. The most popular is Anaconda (conda).

Some software also has specific package managers which can be installed within conda
For example, if you use R, the renv package manages R packages.

For Python, the venv module is similar to conda; you shouldn‚Äôt mix and match them.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Installing conda
You can install conda from their website, for the UI (which is awful)

I prefer Miniconda, which is a very lightweight no-UI solution

https://docs.conda.io/en/latest/miniconda.html
My rationale is that if you‚Äôre using conda you need to be at least a little comfortable with the command line.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
conda Concepts
In conda, you create virtual environments into which you can install software.

An environment is a virtualized space for software
Software is installed using conda via a package manager
Packages come from channels which are online repositories hosted by Anaconda or the community (or you!)
You activate environments to switch into them and then launch software from inside them

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Key conda Commands

conda create --name MYENV

Make a new, empty, environment

conda activate MYENV

Switch into MYENV

conda install -c conda-forge PACKAGE

Install a new package

conda info --envs

Help I forgot the name of my environment

conda list --revisions then conda install --rev 8

I want to go back to revision 8

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Example: A Simple R Workflow
conda create --name R-env
conda activate R-env
conda install -c conda-forge r-essentials
conda install -c r rstudio
conda run rstudio
If you have an external IDE (like RStudio or VSCode) you will also be able to see the R-env environment as one way to ‚Äúrun‚Äù R

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Sharing conda Environments
Okay, you‚Äôve done a bunch of stuff. You want to send your code and workflow to your PI. How do you do that?
conda activate R-env
conda env export > r-environment.yml
Then on the other computer, you just do:
conda env create -f r-environment.yml

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Pitfalls and Problems
A key issue is when you need a package or software that isn‚Äôt available via conda install.

If it‚Äôs a local package (e.g.¬†as in R), you can look into a specific local manager (like renv)
You can create and publish your own package (neat but hard)

Usually best to install using curl from a specific version and then just save that information.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
section: But I hate the command line üò≠
text:
But I hate the command line üò≠
I know, it sucks. Write a short bash script to launch all the stuff you want in your project folder instead. No more scary command line.

Here‚Äôs how to do it: https://comet.arts.ubc.ca/pages/installing_locally.html

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
What is git?
If conda manages software what manages files or data? The answer: git and version control.

git is a version control system which was developed by Linus Torvalds for use with Linux
It is a distributed system, which makes it ideal for large project and collaboration

It keeps track of the changes made to files. While there are other options (e.g., Mercurial) git is by far the most popular and adopted.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Key Pros and Cons?


Pros

Keeps track of changes
Restores old changes
Allows easy sharing
Integrates with cloud deployment
GitHub


Cons

Linus Torvalds
Complex
Overwhelming at first
Many software choices
Command line

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
‚ÄúEasy‚Äù to Use
Fortunately, unless you are working on large projects with lots of co-authors, the basic git workflow is actually easy to use.

You can also install GUIs which make this easier: two popular options are Github Desktop and GitKraken

The benefits of git are similar to LaTeX: it has a learning curve, but once you get the hang on it, everything will else will seem inferior and wrong.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
git Concepts and Terminology
In git, there are many new concepts:

A repository is a collection of files, including a complete history of those files and their changes.
A commit is a revision made to a repository: it is the basic unit of tracking. You stage files to be committed.
A remote is a repository which lives on another computer; a local is one on your computer, usually cloned from it.
A fork refers to a copy of a remote, which lives independently, but shares history
A branch is a version of a repository, main is the ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù or ‚Äúmain‚Äù one.
A merge combines two branches
A pull brings changes from a remote to a local; a push does the opposite.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Basic Idea
I am working with my colleague on a project. We store all our stuff on a private GitHub remote.

I clone her remote repository, to start working locally.
I create a new branch to store my changes. I make some changes.

I want her to check out my changes, so I stage the ones for review and commit them to the branch.
I push the branch to the remote, so she can see it. She pulls my branch and looks at the changes. She makes some edits and commits them.
I pull her edits. We agree things are good. I pull the main branch again, then merge my branch with it.
I push my updated main branch, and delete my old branch.

We just worked on a project together!

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Installing git
You can install git from the website:

https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Getting-Started-Installing-Git

This will give you the software and a Linux-based command-like tool (git bash) and a simple GUI (git gui). You can install other software now:

GitHub Desktop: https://desktop.github.com/
GitKraken: https://www.gitkraken.com/

title: Replicable Research in Economics
section: git Workflow Part 1: Cloning and Branching
text:
git Workflow Part 1: Cloning and Branching




gitGraph
  commit tag: "clone"
  branch my_work
  commit
  commit
  checkout main
  merge my_work
  commit

title: Replicable Research in Economics
section: git Workflow Part 2: Staging and Committing
text:
git Workflow Part 2: Staging and Committing
A bundle of changes to files is called a commit (git commit). You can select only some files by staging them, which is easiest in a GUI.

A commit will create a diff which are the changes made to a file. Check this out! It‚Äôs very helpful.
You can collect all the changes you want to ‚Äúfinalize‚Äù by staging or unstaging the files, then commit them
All commits need a title, and can have comments; use this to help find stuff later

You shouldn‚Äôt commit things every time you save a file. Only commit stuff that you want to mark as a point to go back to; usually after you‚Äôve done some stuff, or hit a milestone.

title: Replicable Research in Economics
section: git Workflow Part 3: Pulling, Merging, and Pushing
text:
git Workflow Part 3: Pulling, Merging, and Pushing




gitGraph
  commit tag: "clone"
  branch my_work
  commit
  commit
  checkout main
  commit
  checkout my_work
  merge main
  commit
  checkout main
  merge my_work
  commit
  checkout my_work
  commit

title: Replicable Research in Economics
section: git Workflow Part 4: F-ing it Up
text:
git Workflow Part 4: F-ing it Up

Git is hard: messing up is easy, and figuring out how to fix your mistakes is impossible. Git documentation has this chicken and egg problem where you can‚Äôt search for how to get yourself out of a mess, unless you already know the name of the thing you need to know about in order to fix your problem. (Katie Sylor-Miller)

https://dangitgit.com/en

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Key Pitfalls

Watch out for binary files such as large images or compiled programs.

Binaries, by their very nature, cannot form simple diffs which means if they are included in a git repo they can increase its size exponentially
A solution is to use the git Large File Storage system instead (https://git-lfs.com/)

Watch out for accidentally committing sensitive material, since it is stored in the history of the repo.

A solution is the BFG Repo Cleaner https://rtyley.github.io/bfg-repo-cleaner/

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Integrating Workflows
At this point, you have an idea of how to make your work completely reproducible.

You have control of the software and the files/data
What about hardware?

Conceptually, this should not matter: but sometimes it does1

The solution is to use continuous integration and continuous deployment tools to build and produce all of your work in the cloud.

Every wonder why as.factor and as_factor exist in R?

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
Server Deployment
To do this, you need a server - but fortunately, GitHub and GitLab exist, and are free.

You can set up a script which pulls a defined image of a software and virtual computer, loads or creates your environment, clones your repo, and then builds your project all in the cloud.
This is the highest level of reproducibility - it‚Äôs not even hard.
For example, here‚Äôs how to build LaTeX documents in GitHub: https://github.com/marketplace/actions/github-action-for-latex
Overleaf even synchronizes with this too: https://www.overleaf.com/learn/how-to/Using_Git_and_GitHub

title: Replicable Research in Economics
text:
References









Brodeur, Abel, Mathias L√©, Marc Sangnier, and Yanos Zylberberg. 2016. ‚ÄúStar Wars: The Empirics Strike Back.‚Äù American Economic Journal: Applied Economics 8 (1): 1‚Äì32.


Christensen, Garret, and Edward Miguel. 2018. ‚ÄúTransparency, Reproducibility, and the Credibility of Economics Research.‚Äù Journal of Economic Literature 56 (3): 920‚Äì80.


Franco, Annie, Neil Malhotra, and Gabor Simonovits. 2014. ‚ÄúPublication Bias in the Social Sciences: Unlocking the File Drawer.‚Äù Science 345 (6203): 1502‚Äì5.


Ioannidis, John PA. 2005. ‚ÄúWhy Most Published Research Findings Are False.‚Äù PLoS Medicine 2 (8): e124.
